posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Over the past couple weeks I’ve written a plugin for ReCalc that calculates optimal PID gains using the same algorithm as SysId - essentially, it adds SysId’s “theoretical mode” to the ReCalc pages for relevant mechanisms types:

image 720×678 48.6 KB

image 720×678 48.6 KB

image 720×678 48.6 KB

I’ve done some trickery to seed the cost function controls (tolerances and max effort) with dimensionally-appropriate values to keep teams out of some potential edge-cases in the algorithm (for details, see the “cost function controls” dropdown).

To my eye, the “default” gains the tool is giving now look very reasonable (provided you have entered accurate mechanism specifications, loop period, and measurement delay) - but the real proof is in hardware testing.  So, I’m putting a request out there for hardware testers willing to try out the default gain recommendations and report back on how well they do.

A hosted beta can be found here .  Please be very careful with units!

Edit: Original demo link had broken the drive and flywheel calculators; just updated with a new link.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
P.S. If anyone wants to donate a pure JS implementation of the matrix power function that correctly handles rational/float-valued exponents, it’d be appreciated; i don’t have the time to tease one out of AI (much less write one from scratch) right now.  There is currently some inaccuracy in the latency compensation when the delay is not an exact multiple of the loop time.

Shoutout to @calcmogul for the reference python implementation for the DARE solver.

Edit: Nevermind; I think I’ve got it worked out.

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked: What is a good way to estimate (or measure) efficiency? Also, how could one measure Measurement Delay? Finally, should loop time be based directly on the hertz of the code, or the measured loop times?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Grumpy_Bud:

What is a good way to estimate (or measure) efficiency?

5-10% multiplicative loss per stage of gearing between the motor and the output (depending on build quality and type of transmission) usually works well enough.

Grumpy_Bud:

Also, how could one measure Measurement Delay?

To actually measure it involves enough hassle that you should just run SysId (which will attempt to measure it for you).  You should be able to infer an approximate value by looking at your motor controller settings and signal chain and applying some critical thinking.

Grumpy_Bud:

Finally, should loop time be based directly on the hertz of the code, or the measured loop times?

It depends on where the control loop is running.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked: I guess this is more of a structural question of wether or not code will run faster if cycle times are lower. I assume it still caps out at 50hz for robot code and 1khz for talonfx controllers?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
What do you mean, whether code will run faster if cycle times are lower?  This is a web tool that generates theoretical gains; it does not directly interact with the robot code.  The loop runs at whatever speed it does; you have no discretion in the tool other than what you can do in code.

Setting the inputs in the tool to values that do not match your code configuration will likely not yield optimal gains (nor necessarily stable ones, for that matter).

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
Grumpy_Bud:

I assume it still caps out at 50hz for robot code and 1khz for talonfx controllers?

Yes, by default the periodic methods of wpilib will be called at a max of 50 Hz. You can (and teams do) set up your own loops to run faster. The code itself does not just run as fast as possible even if cycle times are lower
